taxonomicNotes: Bourdillon named the species as Eugenia rama-varmae during 1904 based on his collection from Chemungi hills (1895) and later Gamble (1919) renamed as Jambosa rama-varma. Later Chithra (1983) placed it as Syzygium rama-varmae (Bourd.) Chithra. The collections of Henry 1979 and Shareef (2001- 2002) extended  its distribution to Kanyakumari Wildlife Sanctuary and Munnar hills of Idukki district respectively. The species is locally termed as Manikiluki since the dried fruits sounds like a bead inside a box (rattle).

authority: Biju, Van Bocxlaer, Mahony, Dinesh, Radhakrishnan, Zachariah, Giri & Bossuyt, 2011
Biju, Van Bocxlaer, Mahony, Dinesh, Radhakrishnan, Zachariah, Giri & Bossuyt, 2011
Biju, Van Bocxlaer, Mahony, Dinesh, Radhakrishnan, Zachariah, Giri & Bossuyt, 2011

Biju, Van Bocxlaer, Mahony, Dinesh, Radhakrishnan, Zachariah, Giri & Bossuyt, 2011

taxonomicNotes: Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
This is a restricted concept of this species which excludes subpopulations which are now assigned to other segregate species in the Amolops monticola group (Patel et al. 2021).
Biju et al. (2014) recognized the species as distinct from Indirana temporalis.

authority: Biju, Garg, Mahony, Wijayathilaka, Senevirathne & Meggaskumbara, 2014

taxonomicNotes: It is possible that there is another species existing under this concept in the northern Western Ghats (A.D. Padhye pers. comm. September 2020).

authority: Biju, Garg, Mahony, Wijayathilaka, Seneviranthne & Meegaskumbura, 2014

taxonomicNotes: Chaitanya et al. (2018) assigned to Micrixalus cf. adonis specimens found in Meghamalai Wildlife Sanctuary, although precise recording sites were not provided and they are not included in the distribution map or extent of occurrence (EOO) until further taxonomic work has been carried out.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Micrixalus sali (Biju et al. 2014). According to Biju et al. (2014), subpopulations from Siruvani and surrounding regions now belong to M. thampii.
This is a split from the broader concept of Micrixalus nudis (Biju et al. 2014).
This is a split from the broader concept of Micrixalus saxicola (Biju et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split into this and Micrixalus herrei (Biju et al. 2014).
This species has been removed from the synonymy of Micrixalus fuscus (Biju et al. 2014).

authority: Ohler, Deuti, Grosjean, Paul, Ayyaswamy, Ahmed & Dutta, 2009

taxonomicNotes:
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Raorchestes hassanensis (Abraham et al. 2015).

Up until recently this species was known only from the type series collected in 1882. It was rediscovered and published as a new species, R. emeraldi, by Vijayakumar et al. (2014), but Abraham et al. (2015) determined that these new specimens actually belonged to this species that had not been recorded for over 100 years.

authority: Abraham, Jobin, Cyriac, Zachariah, Raju & Zachariah, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Syzygium stocksii and S. travancoricum have been merged (Byng et al. 2015) and treated under the earlier valid name S. stocksii.

authority: Dahanukar, Modak, Krutha, Nameer, Padhye & Molur, 2016
Dahanukar, Modak, Krutha, Nameer, Padhye & Molur, 2016
taxonomicNotes: Records from Anamada in the Nelliyampathy Hills of Palakkad district (Afthab et al. 2018) require molecular studies to confirm its presence (N. Modak pers. comm. October 2020).
This species has two varieties; Euphorbia vajravelui var. theniensis B.De Jong & R.W.Stewart and Euphorbia vajravelui var. vajravelui.

The holotype of this species was lost and the type locality is unknown. It was suspected to potentially be in the surroundings of Bhamo in Myanmar but this has not been confirmed. A neotype was assigned by Humtsoe et al. (2008) from Nagaland in northeast India.

Gamble, in 1918, named the species as Syzygium palghatense based on the herbarium specimen collected by Beddome (1872; K! 254) which was described earlier as Eugenia beddomei by Duthie in 1878. The species was rediscovered after a lapse of 140 years with a first time description of the mature fruits (Sujanapal and Sasidharan 2002).

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys major (Mahony et al. 2018). 

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys major (Mahony et al. 2018).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys major (Mahony et al. 2018).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys major (Mahony et al. 2018).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

Mahony et al. (2018) assigned to Megophrys cf. periosa specimens found in the state of Manipur State in India at Pangkava ju in the Ukhrul district, and in the state of Kachin in northern Myanmar at Hepu Stream in Hepu village in the Myitkyina district, at 820 m asl, but their relation to M. periosa requires further taxonomic investigation (S. Mahony pers. comm. September 2020).

authority: Seshadri, Singal, Priti, Ravikanth, Vidisha, Saurabh, Pratik & Gururaja, 2016

taxonomicNotes: The subpopulations in Sri Lanka have been assigned to Indosylvirana serendipi and Hydrophylax gracilis (Biju et al. 2014). These species have all been moved from Indosylvirana and Hydrophylax back to Hylarana (Dubois et al. 2021).
As the species is only known from one specimen, more taxonomic and fieldwork is needed to check the validity of the species.

There are taxonomic difficulties with this species, and it is possible that Ansonia rubigina is a synonym of it (S.D. Biju pers. comm. 2004). We depart from the taxonomy proposed by Dubois et al. (2021), who moved this species to the genus Blaira, on the basis that it was only published as Ghatophryne in an electronic-only journal prior to 2012. This assessment retains it in Ghatophryne, as it is the name registered with ZooBank.
Many museum specimens assigned to Bufo beddomii are misidentifications (Biju 2001).
Records from Kerala are misidentifications (Dinesh et al. 2009).
This species has been moved from the genus Xanthophryne to Beduka by Dubois et al. (2021).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This taxon has now been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

Several species might be currently confused under this name. Specimens collected in the northern part of its range have been found to belong to Fejervarya pierrei Dubois, 1975 (Biju 2001).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the reallocation of syntypes, previously assigned to this species, to Indirana sarojamma (Dahanukar et al. 2016). Records from Maharashtra have been re-assigned to Indirana chiravasi (Dahanukar et al. 2016).
This taxon has been moved to the genus Walkerana (Dahanukar et al. 2016).
This taxon has been moved to the genus Walkerana (Dahanukar et al. 2016).

The holotype of this species is lost, and the designation of a neotype is necessary if this proves to be a valid species. Rao (1937) originally described this species as Philautus elegans, but Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred it from the genus Philautus to Micrixalus.
Some records attributed to this species might not belong to it (India Red List Assessment Workshop 2004).

The original description of this species, as Nyctibatrachus hussaini (Krishnamurthy et al. 2001), did not provide any information about the type specimen. Hence, its taxonomy and nomenclature required further investigation and amendments (Biju 2001, Das and Kunte 2005, S.K. Dutta pers. comm.). Dinesh et al. (2007) provided the replacement name Nyctibatrachus karnatakaensis.
This species was designated a lectotype and its range redelimited by Biju et al. (2011).
Biju et al. (2011) has revised the taxonomy of this species and designated a lectotype.
The holotype of this species is lost, hence Biju et al. (2011) designated a specimen collected in 2007 at Kempholey, Hassan district, Karnataka State as a neotype.

Research into the species validity needs to be prioritised. The key recommended conservation measures include taxonomic research on the generic allocation of this taxon (Das 1998, Chandramouli 2017, Harikrishnan and Vasudevan 2018).
This species has been moved from Chiromantis to Chirixalus, following the removal of the latter genus from synonymy of the former (Chen et al. 2020).

Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) suggested that this species could be a synonym of Ixalus beddomii Günther, 1876. However, subsequent studies indicate that both species are distinct (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Garg et al. 2021).
Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) designated a neotype for this species after the type specimen was lost.

Garg et al. (2021) compared the two known specimens of Raorchestes thodai morphologically with this species and found there was no clear distinction between the two taxa. In addition despite further surveys over the previous decade, no further specimens of Raorchestes thodai have been collected and no observations of individuals, which further supports the likelihood that Raorchestes thodai is a junior synonym of this species (Garg et al. 2021).

Raorchestes punctatus and R. melanensis (collected by Rao in Karnataka) are considered to be synonyms of this species (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001), but further studies are required to confirm this relationship (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This taxon was transfered to the new genus Ghatixalus and is considered to be the sister species of Ghatixalus asterops (Biju et al. 2008).
Transferred from Kaloula to Uperodon (Portik et al. 2023).
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

authority: Biju, Van Bocxlaer, Giri, Roelants, Nagaraju & Bossuyt, 2007

taxonomicNotes:
The species named Fejervarya nicobariensis in the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species was in fact Hylarana nicobariensis. The true Fejervarya nicobariensis was inadvertently omitted from the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red Lists. In 2008 it was assessed. The validity of the species was affirmed by Dubois and Ohler (2000).

This taxon has been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018). There is still some taxonomic uncertainty regards this species, and in particular the range limits need to be determined (S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. 2020).

authority: Sengupta, Hussain, Choudhury, Gogoi, Ahmed & Choudhury, 2008
taxonomicNotes: Assignment to Amolops based on association of topotypic larvae that were not grown to adulthood; the generic assignment is therefore provisional (Frost 2020). Molecular analyses are expected to show that some specimens assigned to this species may belong to a different taxa, although this has not been confirmed (S. Jayaditya pers. comm. September 2020).
This species has undergone a name change from Xanthophryne tigerinus, which was deemed invalid as it was published in an electronic journal only prior to 2012 (Dubois et al. 2021).

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys parva (Mahony et al. 2013).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

This is a split from the broader concept of Megophrys boettgeri (Mahony et al. 2013).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
This species has been resurrected from the synonymy of Nyctibatrachus beddomii by Biju et al. (2007).
This is a split from the broader concept of Minervarya rufescens (as Fejervarya rufescens) by Garg and Biju (2017).

Rao (1937) originally described this taxon as Philautus kottigeharensis based on a single specimen from Kottigehar. Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred the species from Philautus to Micrixalus. The holotype was lost and recently Bossuyt and Milinkovitch (2001) relocated the species from Bhadrea in Chicamangalore District very near to the type locality. 

Micrixalus narainensis and M. swamianus have been synonymised with this species by Biju et al. (2014).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the revalidation of Nyctibatrachus anamallaiensis which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Biju et al. 2007).
This species was designated a lectotype, its range redelimited, and Nyctibatrachus sholai was synonymized within it by Biju et al. (2011).

Formerly placed in genus Erolia. Specific name formerly listed as testacea, but ferruginea has priority. Form described as C. paramelanotos (“Cox’s Sandpiper”) shown to be a hybrid between present species and (almost certainly) C. melanotos; C. (Pisobia) cooperi (“Cooper’s Sandpiper”) probably a hybrid between present species and C. acuminata. Monotypic.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

authority: Chandramouli, Vasudevan, Harikrishnan, Dutta, Janani, Sharma, Das & Aggarwal, 2016

taxonomicNotes: Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Cryptocoryne cognata was lost to science for 150 years until its rediscovery in the 1990s by Indian botanists who found the plant in the district of Ratnagiri in Maharashtra State.

Syzygium sasidharanii was published (Sujanapal et al. 2013) based on their collection from Druryi rock region of Agasthyamalai hills during 2006. The Syzygium chemunjianum published (Shareef et al. 2013) based on their collection from the adjacent Chemunji hills during 2012 was found to be the same taxon and the latter became a synonym of Syzygium sasidharanii.

Sousa plumbea has been recognized as a species since taxonomic revision of the genus Sousa in 2014 (Committee on Taxonomy 2014, Jefferson and Rosenbaum 2014). Previously this species was lumped together with the Indo-Pacific Humpback Dolphin (Sousa chinensis), but animals occurring in the western part of the Indian Ocean from South Africa to western coastline of India are now recognized as taxonomically distinct from those that occur further east, based on genetics, skeletal morphology, external morphology and colour. There is uncertainty about the taxonomic affinities of the Humpback Dolphins that occur in the Bay of Bengal. Animals in this area do not appear to be S. plumbea or S. chinensis, or to be hybrids of the two, and may be a separate taxonomic entity (Amaral et al. 2017; 2020). Additional sampling should confirm the eastern limits of the S. plumbea species, but for the purposes of this assessment we assume it to be Sri Lanka and the southern tip of India in the Gulf of Mannar.
Asarcornis scutulata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Cairina.

Described in genus Plectranthus, the species was later moved to genus Coleus (Paton et al. 2019). The species was described from the same district (Idukki) in Kerala, southern India as Coleus anamudianus (Smitha & Sunojk.) Smitha and Coleus petricola (J.Mathew & B.J.Conn) A.J.Paton.

Trochalopteron fairbanki, T. meridionale, T. jerdoni and T. cachinnans have been moved to the new genus Montecincla after they were found to be sister to a clade composed of Heterophasia, Minla, Actinodura, Leiothrix, Liocichla and Crocias (Robin et al. 2017). They have also received new common names, and are listed as Palani Chilappan Montecincla fairbanki, Ashambu Chilappan M. meridionalis, Banasura Chilappan M. jerdoni and Nilgiri Chilappan M. cachinnans.

T. fairbanki and T. meridionale (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Strophocincla fairbanki following Rasmussen and Anderton (2005).

Trochalopteron fairbanki, T. meridionale, T. jerdoni and T. cachinnans have been moved to the new genus Montecincla after they were found to be sister to a clade composed of Heterophasia, Minla, Actinodura, Leiothrix, Liocichla and Crocias (Robin et al. 2017). They have also received new common names, and are listed as Palani Chilappan Montecincla fairbanki, Ashambu Chilappan M. meridionalis, Banasura Chilappan M. jerdoni and Nilgiri Chilappan M. cachinnans.

T. fairbanki and T. meridionale (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Strophocincla fairbanki following Rasmussen and Anderton (2005).

The genus Paradoxornis has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Elsewhere has been treated as conspecific with P. guttaticollis by some authors, but is morphometrically quite distinct and differs in vocalizations and, especially, in habitat requirements; ranges overlap (or formerly did) in parts of NE India, but the two are ecologically separated. Monotypic.

Previously listed as Chatarrhaea longirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly listed as Turdoides longirostris. Birds reported from SW Myanmar not yet assigned to subspecies. Two subspecies recognized.
This recently described taxon has not yet been treated by Plants of the World online.

Based on morphological analysis, Khorozyan et al. (2006) recognize Panthera pardus tulliana (Valenciennes, 1856) in western Türkiye and P. p. sindica (Pocock, 1930) in Pakistan, and possibly also parts of Afghanistan and Iran. They also consider P. p. ciscaucasica (Satunin, 1914) as the senior synonym for P. p. saxicolor.

Kitchener et al. (2017) in their revised taxonomy of the Felidae recognize the following eight Leopard subspecies:
  • Panthera pardus pardus (Linnaeus, 1758): Africa
  • Panthera pardus tulliana (Valenciennes, 1856; 1039): Türkiye, Caucasus, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Iran, Iraq, Afghanistan and Pakistan
  • Panthera pardus fusca (Meyer, 1794): Indian subcontinent, Burma and China
  • Panthera pardus kotiya Deraniyagala, 1949: Sri Lanka
  • Panthera pardus delacouri Pocock, 1930b: Southeast Asia and probably southern China
  • Panthera paruds orientalis (Schlegel, 1857) including japonensis: Eastern Asia from Russian Far East to China
  • Panthera pardus melas (Cuvier, 1809; 152): Java
  • Panthera pardus nimr (Hemprich and Ehrenberg, 1832): Arabian Peninsula.

The treatment by Kitchener et al. (2017) is followed by the IUCN Red List.
Calidris subruficollis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Tryngites.

Three subspecies of Banteng have come to be generally recognised (Lekagul and McNeely 1977, National Research Council 1983):
1. Bos javanicus javanicus on Java and Bali,
2. B. j. lowi on Borneo, and
3. B. j. birmanicus on the Asian mainland.

Grzimek (1990) argued against separating these local forms into true subspecies because a number of the small populations of wild Banteng which remain have been affected by interbreeding with domestic or feral cattle. Corbet and Hill (1992) did not recognise any valid subspecies of Banteng either. Frequent reports of interbreeding between wild Banteng and domestic livestock on Borneo (S. Hedges pers. comm. 2008) have yet to be substantiated in Sabah and Java (J. Burton pers. comm. 2016). Phylogenetic studies of B. j. lowi are confounded by the difficulties of obtaining samples. Recent genetic studies have produced contradicting results with regards to the taxonomic status of Banteng on Borneo. Mitochondrial DNA evidence suggested that the Bornean and Javan Banteng have such large genetic distances as to constitute separate species (Ishige et al. 2016, Handayani 2023). However, nuclear genomic data refutes this hypothesis and suggests that Bornean Banteng affiliates strongly with the Javan Banteng (Sun et al. 2022).

Until there is sufficient information on its genetic description, current population size, and status of B. j. lowi should not be included within B. javanicus. Pending further morphometric and genetic analysis Bos j. javanicus and B. j. birmanicus are provisionally accepted here in recognition of the relatively pronounced phenotypic differences which exist between Banteng on Java and the Asian mainland.
Calidris falcinellus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Limicola.

Belocercus longicaudus (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously listed as Psittacula longicauda (del Hoyo et al. 2014). Braun et al. (2019) report the situation where the parrot genera Psittinus, Tanygnathus and Mascarinus nest genetically within Psittacula, meaning that either Psittacula replaces these latter three genera or it breaks down into monophyletic genera of their own. The latter course is preferred, building on Braun et al. (2016), where several genera were established or resurrected including Belocercus for P. longicauda.

Formerly included in the subfamily Acinonychinae which is a monophyletic group, (e.g., Wozencraft 1993), molecular evidence now clusters the Cheetah with the Puma (Puma concolor) and Jaguarundi (Herpailurus yagouaroundi) in the tribe Acinonychini, diverging some 6.9 million years ago (Johnson et al. 2006, O'Brien and Johnson 2007). A close relationship between these three species is in agreement with earlier studies (Johnson and O’Brien 1997, Bininda-Emonds et al. 1999, Mattern and MacLennan 2000). The English name is derived from the Hindi Chita, meaning "spotted one". The generic name Acinonyx is a reference to its semi-retractile claws (Caro 1994).

Kitchener et al. (2017) recognize four subspecies:
  • Acinonyx jubatus jubatus (Schreber 1775) distributed across southern and eastern Africa. This subspecies combines two subspecies previously documented by Smithers (1975): Acinonyx jubatus jubatus (Schreber 1775) and Acinonyx jubatus raineyi (Heller 1913; 9)
  • Acinonyx jubatus soemmeringii (Fitzinger, 1885) distributed across northeastern Africa
  • Acinonyx jubatus venaticus (Griffith, 1821) distributed across southwestern Asia and India
  • Acinonyx jubatus hecki (Hilzheimer, 1913) distributed across western and northwestern Africa
The authors note that further genetic analysis is needed to assess whether these subspecies designations are appropriate, or whether there needs to be further consolidation.

For many decades the genus Arctonyx was universally considered monospecific, under the oldest available name, A. collaris. It has been proposed that the genus contains multiple species: Sumatran Hog Badger A. hoevenii is disjunct from the rest of the genus's range, whilst Northern Hog Badger A. albogularis and Greater Hog Badger A. collaris (sensu stricto) occur in mainland Asia, with a poorly understood zone of overlap or contact (Helgen et al. 2008). This revision was not accepted by Choudhury (2013) who furthermore queried the neotype and accompanying type locality selected for A. collaris by Helgen et al. (2008). Nonetheless, Helgen et al. (2008: 369) were explicit that "the absolute, striking distinctions in size, pelage and qualitative cranial morphology between available adult samples of A. albogularis and A. collaris indicate no intergradation between these taxa". Therefore, three species of hog badger are recognized here.

Wangchuk et al. (2003) described a new subspecies, Trachypithecus geei bhutanensis, from Bhutan in the north of the range, with T. g. geei occurring in the south, the two taxa being separated by the Main Frontal Thrust (MFT) of the Indian plate hitting into the Himalayas (Bhargava 1997). However, T. g. bhutanensis is not recognised here as a valid subspecies, as it has not been described according to ICZN rules.

Four subspecies were recognized by Groves (2005), although their validity was in some doubt as it was thought that seasonal variation in pelage colour may account for at least some variation. This has been reviewed recently and distinct hair patterns have been used (Choudhury 2014). Choudhury (2014) recognizes three subspecies: Trachypithecus pileatus pileatus, T. p. brahma and T. p. tenebricus.

Taxonomy currently used by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group (see Kitchener et al. 2017):

Panthera leo leo—Central Africa, West Africa and Asia
Panthera leo melanochaita—Southern and East Africa

Lions were previously described as two subspecies: the African Lion (Panthera leo leo) and the Asiatic Lion (Panthera leo persica). However, this has subsequently changed.

Recent studies (Bertola et al. 2015, 2016, 2022) indicate that lions in Western and Central Africa are more closely related to lions found in India than they are to those found in Southern and East Africa. This is likely the result of lions being reduced to local refugia during the more recent part of the Pleistocene climatic cycles (Bertola et al. 2011, 2016). Divergence times estimated from genetic data match large-scale changes in habitat, including expansion and contraction of forested areas, possibly reducing connectivity and isolating Lion subpopulations (Bertola et al. 2016). This temporary isolation may have led to divergence of subpopulations, which can still be observed today. Historical connectivity between Lion subpopulations in West or Central African and subpopulations in India explain the close evolutionary relationships between these subpopulations, even though a series of bottlenecks have led the Indian subpopulation to differentiate quickly as a result of increased genetic drift (Bertola et al. 2015, 2016). Based on recent genetic studies, the two subspecies of lions overlap in a contact zone in Ethiopia which possibly extends into Sudan and South Sudan (Bertola et al. 2015, 2016, 2021, 2022).
